data.title: Happy birthday, Michael! As one of basketball's greatest players turns 50, Sportsmail looks back at Jordan's remarkable career
data.meta_description: As one of sport's true greats turns 50 today, we've decided to cast our eyes back over Michael Jordan's illustrious career and colourful life so far.
data.text:
Advertisement

As one of sport's true greats turns 50 today, we've decided to cast our eyes back over Michael Jordan's illustrious career and colourful life so far.

The NBA Hall of Famer is best known for his time spent with the Chicago Bulls - the basketball team he joined after dazzling with the University of North Carolina in the early Eighties.

As well as shining bright throughout a professional basketball career which spanned across three decades, Brooklyn-born Jordan has been voted the greatest North American athlete of the 20th century, tried his hand at baseball, bought an NBA team and even starred in a hit movie alongside Bugs Bunny.

Here, we give you 50 incredible pictures to celebrate each year of Jordan's remarkable life and 50 'MJ by numbers' facts about the great man.

Michael and the Chicago Bulls: Jordan shot to prominence in the NBA when he arrived on scene in 1984

The world watches: Michael Jordan flies through the air with his eyes on the basket at a 1988 NBA Slam Dunk contest

Never in doubt: Jordan drops the ball in with the style and grace basketball fans became so accustomed to

Slam dunk: Jordan remains one of the greatest professional basketball players the NBA has ever seen. He turns 50 today

Icon: Jordan lit up the NBA with his incredible ability for the Chicago Bulls. In these images, the superstar sports the red kit of his former team

Steely: Jordan joined the Bulls from North Carolina in the 1984 NBA draft and instantly became a fans favourite in Chicago

Heroics: Jordan made the No 23 his own during his spells at the Chicago Bulls. Here, he battles with Portland Trailblazers' Brian Grant under the net

Eyes on the prize: Jordan leaves defenders in his wake as he leaps to drop the ball in to take two points against Utah Jazz as he cruises past an opposing defender (right)

Nice try: Jordan retains the ball with his back to Anthony Mason of the Charlotte Hornets in a best-of-seven series match

Talented: Jordan wriggles past David Wesley (right) of the Charlotte Hornets dressed in the white strip of the Bulls (left)

Fever pitch: Jordan shoots for the basket as San Antonio Spurs' David Greenwood watches the rising star in the 1986 match (left) as he eyes another basket (right)

Born winner: Jordan and Bulls coach Phil Jackson hold their MVP and NBA championship trophies after beating Utah Jazz to the NBA championship in 1998

Powerless: Karl Malone of Utah Jazz (left) can only watch as Jordan rises above him, as Jordan is sandwiched against the New York Knicks (right)

VIDEO: MICHAEL JORDAN'S TOP TEN SLAM DUNKS

Michael the rising star: Jordan during his time with the University of North Carolina

The early days: Jordan, who is also known affectionately as MJ, played for the University of North Carolina before being drafted in by the Chicago Bulls

Tussle: Jordan (right) competes with Syracuse's Dwayne "Pearl" Washington as the pair wait for the ball

Remember the name: Jordan surges through the centre of the court against Syracuse

Youthful: Jordan's dorm identification card from North Carolina shows one of the greatest sportsmen of a generation as a young man

Michael the Olympian: Jordan won two goal medals, one coming in Barcelona in 1992

Michael and baseball: Jordan left the Chicago Bulls in 1993 to try his hand at another sport

Change of tack: Jordan retired for the first of three times from basketball to play baseball with Minor League team Chicago White Sox in 1994

26. In 1992, Jordan starred alongside Bugs Bunny in a commercial during Super Bowl XXVI. The advert inspired the idea for the 1996 movie Space Jam.

27. Jordan returned from his first retirement in time for the business end of the 1994-95 season. He played 27 games during that campaign, the last of which was in a 4-2 playoff loss to Orlando.

28. Jordan averaged 28.2 points per game in his rookie season with a shooting accuracy of 51.5%.

29. In the 1984-85 season, MJ’s rookie season, Jordan averaged 29.3 points per game in the post-season. Incredibly, that was his lowest playoff points per game average ever.

30. Jordan has the highest regular-season career scoring average of 30.1 points per game, just ahead of Chamberlain.

Returning hero: Jordan, having shocked the basketball world, went back to the Chicago Bulls in 1995 after a short spell playing baseball

Michael the Wizard: Jordan returned after a second retirement to play for Washington in 2001

Back again: Jordan returned from his second retirement in 2001. This time he took up the mantle for the Washington Wizards

Still got it: Jordan turned 40 in his second season at the Washington Wizards and played in yet another NBA All-Stars game while with the capital club

Charged: Jordan backs into New Jersey Jets' Richard Jefferson (left) as he seeks to notch up some more points

Michael the movie star: Jordan hit the big screen with the Looney Tunes in 1996

Movie star: Jordan appeared alongside the likes of Bugs Bunny (left) in the 1996 film Space Jam

VIDEO: MICHAEL JORDAN'S APPEARANCE ON 'MY WIFE AND KIDS'

Michael without basketball: Jordan quit the sport he loves once and for all in 2003

Hall of famer: Johnson is pictured alongside coach John Thompson in Springfield, Massachusetts

Keeping busy: Jordan, who now owns the Charlotte Bobcats, watches players go through their predraft training in June last year

Public appearance: Jordan (right) is pictured on stage with chat-show host Oprah Winfrey (left) in 2011

Happy: Jordan (right) is pictured with his fiancee Yvette Prieto (left) in 2011 in Las Vegas

41. In January 2002, Jordan played 41 minutes for Washington against his old team Chicago. The Wizards won the game 77-69 in Illinois and MJ scored 16 points.

42. Jordan played all 82 regular-season games in 1995-96 and made 111 of 260 three-point attempts, an accuracy of 42.7%

43. In Jordan’s second season, he averaged 43.7 points per game in the 1985-86 playoffs. Unfortunately it wasn’t enough for Chicago to avoid a first-round exit.

44. On April 18, 1998 Jordan played his final regular-season game for Chicago. He scored 44 points in a 111-109 win against New York Knicks.

45. Jordan’s favourite number as a child was 45 but he couldn’t wear that when he started playing basketball because his brother Larry was already wearing it, according to reports.

Sponsorships: Jordan has made millions of dollars with his long-running deal with sports brand Nike

Moving on: Jordan waits on the first tee during the morning foursome matches for the Ryder Cup at Medinah in 2012

Jordan, pictured at the 2012 Ryder Cup (left) and the 2006 competition (right) became the first former NBA player to take ownership of a team with the Charlotte Bobcats
